summary: Money laundering refers to the illicit process of concealing the origins of illegally obtained money, often involving complex transactions across various jurisdictions, including those like Monaco and Guernsey. The EU actively engages in countering this crime through stringent regulations and ordinances, aligning with the Financial Action Task Force (FATF) standards. Jurisdictions are required to scrutinise financial activities to prevent recirculation of laundered funds. The judiciary plays a crucial role in enforcing sentences against offenders, including those involved in counterfeiting and forgery. Reforming legal frameworks and enhancing the fitness of regulatory measures are essential for effective deterrent strategies against money laundering and related terrorist financing activities.
